body:
> This poses problems for developers attempting to target the Oculus Rift, particularly if they're using cloned displays, as the top level monitor only identifies itself by the name of "Generic PnP Monitor".

Can you elaborate please? What are the problems exactly, how do they manifest.

Sorry, a bit of it was my own confusion about how EnumDisplayDevices works, as I was confusing the two levels of data it provides about 'adapters' and 'displays' with 'screens' and 'monitors'.  However, the problem I'm having is still an issue.  I have three output monitors, two conventional screens and the Oculus Rift.  

The Oculus SDK provides me the display device name in the format "\\.\DISPLAY1\Monitor0", but there's no way to correlate this with the glfw monitor information.  I'm making an attempt to fix it by modifying the _glfwPlatformGetMonitors implementation to iterate over all the displays for an adapter, not just the first one, and adding a GLFWAPI const char \* glfwGetWin32DeviceName(GLFWmonitor\* monitor); method in the native API.  Once I've got the Windows implementation working I'll try the Linux and OSX versions as well.

> Oculus SDK provides me the display device name in the format "\.\DISPLAY1\Monitor0"

Oh. If I understand you correctly, the problem is that GLFW only exposes the "screens", not physical "monitors". But an external API you're using works with physical "monitors", and you're unable to correlate the two.

Given that it's not GLFW's business to be modifying anything to do with physical monitors (that's up to the user and the OS), it makes sense that the original API only exposed virtual screens (the domain where GLFW plays).

I wonder how to best solve this. There's the approach of exposing physical screens (in read-only form) in GLFW, and another approach is get external APIs to use the virtual screens the way GLFW does. Just thinking out loud.

Well, there may a case for GLFW being concerned with the physical monitor, fullscreen modes.  I'm not certain what happens if I tell glfw to go fullscreen on a cloned monitor, whether it will target both the displays, or just the one that got returned by the platform specific enumeration.  I'll do a test to find out shortly.

A cloned monitor is a high-level abstraction handled by the OS. A normal application doesn't need to be aware whether it's on a cloned display or not.

There is the exception of special programs, like Powerpoint, that do care about (and are able to control) this. Is that what you're referring to?

I guess my major issue is basically 'how do I correlate the display identifier given by the Oculus SDK with a GLFWmonitor instance.  I supposes that I can iterate over the monitors provided by glfw and compare the positions of each with the desktop position provided for the Oculus device.

I don't think that's a good long-term solution, there should be a better one. It's a matter of figuring out where the correct place to fix this would be: is it in the GLFW API, or in the Oculus SDK API?
@jherico I don't mind adding specific code for identifying a Rift, if that's what it takes. Your proposed addition is one alternative. I'll have a look at the Rift SDK and see if there's another.

[Looks like](https://developer.oculusvr.com/doc/html/class_o_v_r_1_1_h_m_d_info.html) it's using a `CGDirectDisplayID` on OS X, so on both systems it's using the same ID that GLFW uses internally. That's good.
As a temporary but portable hack, matching virtual desktop positions will likely get you the right GLFW monitor object.
Access to native monitor IDs has been added with 16eb97d. You will have to convert the encoding of one of the strings on Win32, though, as the Rift SDK provides an ASCII-encoded name.

issue.body:
For some applications the identification of the monitor by display name is not sufficient, and it is useful to use the EDID (e.g. when interfacing with Oculus)

For ths reason I suggest to add a new function: glfwGetMonitorId(monitor) that returns the unique identifier of the monitor.

For OSX this should return: ns.displayID corresponding to CGDirectDisplayID

For Windows this is the DeviceID filled in DISPLAY_DEVICE when EnumDisplayDevices is provided with EDD_GET_DEVICE_INTERFACE_NAME

Best,
Emanuele

body: I was actually curious about that.  You do conversion of the WCHAR to standard char for the display name made available by glfwGetMonitorName, but that's presumably because the latter API is cross-platform, and so the wide characters would be unsuitable.  But might it not also be reasonable to provide this device string as a char \* as well by using the same narrowing functionality, or alternatively using the ascii functions directly, like EnumDisplayDevicesA and DISPLAY_DEVICEA.  I'm a big fan of the views expressed at http://www.utf8everywhere.org/ and prefer avoiding touching non-8-bit chars if I can possibly avoid it.  If not, I'll cope.

Actually, it occurs to me that this won't work in all situations.  This goes back to my original comments about the iteration of the monitors done in win32_monitors.c.  If I have a cloned display, the GLFW monitors only picks up one of the clones, whichever is at index 0, because it only ever calls EnumDisplayDevices for a given adapter with a 0 index:  https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/win32_monitor.c#L142

The display string from the output loop is something like ////.//DISPLAY0 ////.//DISPLAY1 while the inner loop provides names like ////.//DISPLAY1/Monitor0 and  ////.//DISPLAY1/Monitor1 (using forward slash cause git seems to be wigging out on backslash).  In the case of the cloned display, glfw will pretty much always return  ////.//DISPLAY1/Monitor0 for the cloned display, while the Oculus SDK might be returning ////.//DISPLAY1/Monitor1, because the former represents the monitor and the latter represents the actual Rift hardware.  

The only way I can see to resolve this would be for glfw to provide all the platform specific monitors in its list, regardless of whether they're cloned or not, essentially doing an inner loop in the win32_monitor.c function mentioned above, similar to the code in the first answer to this stack overflow question: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9524309/enumdisplaydevices-function-not-working-for-me

The downside is that multiple GLFW monitors will now be reporting the exact same video mode and positions.  An alternative might be a glfwFindMonitor(void *) that takes either a displayID or a char \* (depending on the platform) and finds the GLFWmonitor that corresponds to the requested device string.  In the case of cloned displays it would have to be smart enough to do the two levels of EnumDisplayDevices and be able to correlate the device string provided with whichever monitor might be cloned to that display.
Note that the latest Oculus SDK installs a service that no longer treats the Rift as a regular monitor. The user can opt to disable this, at the cost of higher latency.

This is only supported on Win32 so far.
